title: Tortworth Court
text:
Tortworth Court is a <a href="Victorian%20architecture">Victorian</a> <a href="mansion">mansion</a> in <a href="Tortworth">Tortworth</a> near <a href="Thornbury%2C%20South%20Gloucestershire">Thornbury</a>, <a href="South%20Gloucestershire">South Gloucestershire</a>. England. It was built in <a href="Tudor%20Style%20architecture">Tudor</a> style for the <a href="Henry%20Reynolds-Moreton%2C%202nd%20Earl%20of%20Ducie">2nd Earl of Ducie</a>. It is a Grade II* <a href="listed%20building">listed building</a>.
History.
The mansion was built, in <a href="Tudor%20Style%20architecture">Tudor</a> style, for the <a href="Henry%20Reynolds-Moreton%2C%202nd%20Earl%20of%20Ducie">2nd Earl of Ducie</a> between 1848 and 1853. Its architect was <a href="Samuel%20Sanders%20Teulon">Samuel Sanders Teulon</a>.
During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> the mansion became a naval training base for coding and signals, under the name of HMS Cabbala, and a mast was erected in the high reception hall. After the war, the buildings constructed for the hospital and, for a time the house itself, became <a href="HM%20Prison%20Leyhill">HM Prison Leyhill</a>. Tortworth Court was then used as a training school for prison officers.
The property was designated a <a href="Listed%20building">Grade II* listed</a> by <a href="English%20Heritage">English Heritage</a> on 9 July 1991. By the 1990s, however, it had become derelict, and suffered a large fire in 1991. It was thereafter restored to its original style and extended at a reputed cost of £20 million. In June 2001 it reopened as a hotel operated by <a href="Principal%20Hotel%20Company">Principal Hotel Company</a>.
Arboretum.
Tortworth Court is especially notable for its extensive <a href="arboretum">arboretum</a> developed by <a href="Henry%20Reynolds-Moreton%2C%203rd%20Earl%20of%20Ducie">the 3rd Earl of Ducie</a>, who began planting upon inheriting the property from his father in 1853 and continued until his death in 1921. The collection has fine examples of <a href="rhododendron">rhododendron</a>, <a href="Pinophyta">conifer</a>, <a href="oak">oak</a> and <a href="maple">maple</a>. The arboretum once surrounded the property and continues to be maintained and supported. Accessible by a public footpath, it is now divided between the hotel grounds, the grounds of Leyhill Prison, the Dell which is privately owned and managed as a community woodland by <a href="https%3A//tortwortharboretum.org/">Tortworth Forest Centre CIC</a>, and private land still owned and farmed by the Ducie family. Rivalling at the time the collection of George Holford at nearby <a href="Westonbirt%20Arboretum">Westonbirt Arboretum</a>, it still contains, despite the ravages of time, more than 300 specimens, including unusual and <a href="rare%20species">rare species</a> and many fine specimen trees.
Tortworth Court gave its name to <a href="GWR%202900%20Class">Saint class</a> steam locomotive No. 2955 operated by the <a href="Great%20Western%20Railway">Great Western Railway</a>.
